instNote: ﻿On Sunday, besides the high Mass at 10 o'clock, at which there is an English and a French sermon alternately, there is Mass and a sermon in the German language at 9 o'clock. After Vespers, there is a meeting of the Confraternity of the Rosary.

Unnamed: 30: ﻿https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dardenne_Prairie,_Missouri ; https://genealogytrails.com/mo/stcharles/hist_towns.htm ; These sources say that the present church did not open until 1880, so it is hard to say where this church actually was

﻿https://icnewmadrid.com/church-history ; 1833 almanac mentions no name for the church, but the 1860s/70s almanacs mention a St. John. The church site says that said church(es) came after the war. This means that this one in the 1833 almanac is likely the precursor.
﻿There are too many in later years to say definitively which one this refers to. For that reason, I am leaving it as a generic 9000 ID.
﻿As above, I don't think that there is any clear case for this being one specific place that shows up later in the 1860s/1870s diocese.

NOTES: ﻿English, Orthography, Reading, Writing, Arithmetic, English and French, Grammar and Composition, Geography, Sacred and Profane History, Ancient and Modern Chronology, Mythology, Poetical Composition, Rhetoric, Philosophy, Chemistry, Astronomy, Use of the Maps and Globes.
